720056f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720056f-a.text:
Gramercv Park South, south side, vest from Irvicng Place to
Fourth Avenue where this thoroumhfare resumes its identity as
E. 2Oth Street. The vacant 1ot (No. 17) at the left was formerly
the site of the former residence of Aribassador Gerard and will
be improved by a low duplex a.artment house according to the
ew York Times of February 25, 1938. West of same are the Players
and the National Arts Clubs. The office strurture seen at the
right is at the S.W. corner of Fourth Avenue and E. 20th Street.
June 1U, 1938.
P.L. Sperr
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
Side ~22
720056f-a.folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY

720052f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720052f-a.text:
Gramercy Park South (extreme foreground) north side, at the head of
Irving Place, showing the main gate entrance to Gramercy Park and a view
northward of Lexington Ave. from its commencement point at Gramercy Park
North. The 16-story building, on the left is the Hotel Gramercy Park
at the N.W. corner of Gramercy Park North and Lexington Ave. and bearing
Nos. 52 and 2, respectively on the above mentioned two streets. On the
right is the 12-story building No. 1 Lexington Ave. Also shown in the
center of the Park is a statue of Edwin Booth in the role of Hamlet.
It was sculptured by Edmond T. Quinn in commemoration of the great Shakes-
perean actor who lived in this area.
About 1932.
Ewing Galloway.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
720052f-a.folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY

720046f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720046f-a.text:
16 and 14-15 Gramercy Park South (left to right), south side, west of
Irving Place. No. 14-15 is the National Arts Club building; formerly
the home of Samuel J. Tilden, one of the founders of the New York Public
Library. No. 16 is the home of the Players Club; former residence of
Valentine G. Hall and later of Edwin Booth who founded the Club and
presented them the house as a gift.
June 1925.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
Ne ~26A
720046f-a.folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY

720053f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720053f-a.text:
(1)
Gramercy ParkSouth, at Irving Place, showing the Parkside, a 17-
story residential hotel at the S.W. corner and bearing No. 18. Also
shown is a portion of Gramercy Park. The park is for the exclusive
use of residents of the Gramercy Park development.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, another view.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
720053f-a.folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY

720055f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720055f-a.text:
Gramercy Park South, at Irving Place (photographer's vantage
point), looking northwestward across Gramercy Park, and showing
buildings encircling same upon their respective thoroughfares
known as Gramercy Fark North (right) and Gramercy Park West (left).
Under completion is the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company Building
at the S.E. corner of Madison AVenue and East 24th Street. Note
Calvary Church (P.E.) nestling beneathn same. This edifice occupies
a site at the N.E. corner of Fourth .venue and E. 21st Street.
About 1905.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
Ne w U026A
i1.N 8~2

720051f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720051f-a.text:
Gramercy Park South, north side, (extreme foreground), at the head of
Irving Place, showing the main gate entrance to Gramercy Park and across
it a view nonthward of Lexington Ave., from its point of commencement
at Gramercy Park North. In the center of the Park is seen a statue of
Edwin Booth, greatest Shakesperean actor, in the role of Frince Hamlet,
which was sculptured by Edmond T. Quinn. In the background (right to left)
are shown the Chrwsler and Chanin Buildings on opposing corners at East
42nd Street. From right to left, across the Park, appear Nos. 45
Gramercy Park North; No. 1 Lexington Ave. (N.E. corner) and No. 52 Gramercy
Park North (N.W. corner).
July 11, 1932.
New York Edison Company.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
720051f-a.folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY

720054f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720054f-a.text:
(1)
Gramercy Park South (from left foreground to center of view),
west from and including Irving Place, to and including Gramercy Park
West (right), and showing the Parkside, a 17-story residential hotel,
a the S.W. corner of Irving Place. Also shown is the northwestern
portion of Gramercy Park. It is a private park, for the exclusive
use of residents of this residential development.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

720048f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720048f-a.text:
20 to 23 Gramercy Park South (left), at, adjoining and east of the
S.E. corner of Irving Place. No. 20, the corner house, is the former
residence of Hamilton Fish, one time U.S. Secretary of State, and No.
21, that of John Bigelow, former U.S. Minister to France and joint
editor with Bryant of the New York Post. Also shown (right) is Irving
Place, at, adjoining and south of the S.E. corner of Gramercy Park
South, showing a 3-story stable of the Fish mansion and contiguous to it
Nos. 84 and 82. The Fish House, does not bear Irving Place numbers even
though its entrance is upon same.
March 1909.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
720048f-a.folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY

720047f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720047f-a.text:
19 to 25 Gramercy Park South, at, adjoining and east of the S.E.
corner of Irving Place, and showing the southeastern portion of Gramercy
Park. At the extreme right appears, in part, the Parkside, at the S.A.
corner of Irving Place. No. 19-2O is known as the Stuyvesant Chambers;
and No. 21 was the residence of John Bigelow, once U.S. Minister to
France and joint editor with Bryant, of the New York Evening Post.
July 7, 1928.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
720047f-a.folder: Gramercy Park South & Irving Place, Manhattan, NY

720050f-a.title: Manhattan: Gramercy Park South - Irving Place
720050f-a.text:
Gramercy Park South (extreme foreground), north side, at the head of
Irving Place, showing the main gate to Gramercy Park, and across a view
northward of Lexington Ave., from Gramercy Jark North, (where it begins).
The statue appearing in the center of the Park is that of Edwin Booth in
the role of 'rince Hamlet, which was sculptured by Edmond T. Quinn.
Shown in the background is the Chrysler Building (right) and Chanin
Building on upper Lexington Ave., at East 42nd Street.
July 11, 1932.
New York Edison Company.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
